Text:
(I fend off this churchly brainwashing from dawn to 
dusk, and at last we arrive in the Sacred Land of
Lindwurm.)

(A grand cathedral stands on terrain that looks like
it has been cut out of the mountains, and beneath it
spreads a city with mainly white buildings.)

(The main street running through the heart of the
city leads straight to the long stairway up to the
cathedral and is packed with throngs of tourists.)

(We walk along the main street while checking out the
street vendors that line it.)

(I spot a small trinket, like ones you see at tourist
spots in Japan, with the motif of a dragon coiled
around a sword. Guess some things are the
same no matter what world you're in.)

(The fact that, for some reason, this one has an evil-
looking left arm wrapped around the blade instead of
a dragon catches my interest, so I pick it up.)
Wonder why they’re all left arms...

This land is said to be where the hero Olivier
severed the left arm of the vile Diablos.

Within the surface of the steep mountains surrounding
the Sacred Land are some ruins called the Sanctuary
where Diablos' left arm is supposedly sealed away.
Huh. Guess that explains the swords and arms.
They make popular souvenirs for men.
I'll bet. Sorry, can I get one of these?

I buy one of the trinkets for Skel. 3,000 zeni,
so not too bad.

Rose and I continue to stroll down the street
together.
*gasp*

There's a book-signing session with Natsume Kafka! 
I'm a huge fan of hers!
Natsume Kafka?

She's a popular novelist with the most wonderfully
inventive ideas and a unique worldview that I find
very compelling.

She can write romance, mysteries, action, 
fairytales...and even pure literature!

Her talents span all genres, giving her so much
diversity it's almost like a different person is
writing each book!

Sounds like anything's possible with her. Almost like
she was reincar— Uh, never mind, never mind.
Rose joins the line for autographs.

(I don't have anything better to do, so I may as well
have a look at one of these books.)
("The Midsummer Natsume Collection," eh?)
(Okay.)

(Nah, I'm sure there just happened to be some
literary genius here in this world who had the
same ideas.)

("I Am a Dragon," "Romeo and Julietta,"
"Asherella"...)

("Little Crimson Riding Hood," "Star Trap,"
"One Peace"...)

("Dragon Beer," "The Eminences"... I can't read this
stuff.)

(But yeah. Any ripoffs this fresh can't be a
coincidence.)

(It's gotta be someone who was reincarnated like me...
I need to look into this!)
I get into the line to meet this Natsume Kafka.

The line moves forward as I come up with a game plan,
and soon enough it's my turn.

Natsume has pretty silver hair cut to shoulder length
and a beauty mark under her blue feline eyes. Her
blouse is open at the top, offering a glimpse of her
deep cleavage.
(What the hell is she up to?)
Place your book here.

There is no mistaking it—this is someone I know all
too well. Yep, it's Beta.

As I watch her scratch off her signature with a
practiced hand, I can't stop myself from asking
her a question.
You doing well for yourself?

Could be better, but I'm steadily making a name for
myself. And I owe it all to my lord's wisdom...
(First Gamma, now her...)

(I knew Beta liked literature, so I told her a few
stories from my previous life.)

(I'd only done it half-jokingly, saying she should
come up with some cool stuff of her own based
on them...)
(But I never thought she'd copy them word for word.)
There you are.
You'll find the details of the plan here.
(Ah, Beta. You disappoint me.)
I didn't know you were a fan of Natsume too, Cid.
Nah, not really.

Look at this! I had her do a custom note with my
name in it!

(There's nothing more cheeky than signing
autographs.)
Did you get her to add your name, too?
I did, now that you mention it.

(Beta did mention something about writing details for
some plan in my copy.)
Are those ancient letters?

(It looks really slick, like a secret code. I gave up
trying to learn the ancient alphabet a while back,
so I'm super-fascinated by it.)
Looks that way. Can you read it?

Well, knowing ancient script isn't required, and I
can only make out a few symbols, I'm afraid...

What's more, it seems it’s written in the modern
equivalent of cursive, so I’m not sure I could
make it out, even if I was fluent.
Wow.
But why would she sign your book in ancient letters?
Well... because it's cool, I bet.
Because...it's cool?
Yeah. Cool.
I guess that’s the kind of thing that appeals to men.

(We check into a top-class luxury hotel, where I part
ways with Rose since she had to go make the rounds
saying hi to the other bigwigs.)

(I pay exactly zero zeni. Being an extra that mooches
off the rich might just be the best thing ever. If I turn a
blind eye to the religious zealotry, this path may be
worth some consideration.)

(Unfortunately, I've decided to keep religion at
arm's length.)

(But if I do ever embrace it, that will only be when
I've found my own faith.)
